sen.j: 玉置神社（たまきじんじゃ）は、奈良県吉野郡にある神社。
sen.e: Tamaki-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture.
Tamaki-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture.
Tamaki-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 大峰山の霊山の一つである玉置山の頂上に位置し、高野山などとともに2004年7月に『紀伊山地の霊場と参詣道』として国際連合教育科学文化機関の世界遺産に登録された。
sen.e: It is located on top of Mt. Tamaki, one of the sacred mountains of the Omine Range, and it is part of "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range", which was registered as a world heritage site by UNESCO along with Koya san in July, 2004.

It is located on top of Mt. Tamaki, one of the sacred mountains of the Omine Range, and it is part of "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range", which was registered as a world heritage site by UNESCO along with Koya san in July, 2004.

It is located on top of Mt. Tamaki, one of the sacred mountains of the Omine Range, and it is part of "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range," which was registered as a world heritage site by UNESCO along with Mt. Koya in July, 2004.
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動しました。用語統一しました。

sen.j: 大峯奥駈道の第10番の行所である。
sen.e: It is the tenth Gyosho (training place for ascetics) of Omine Okugake-michi (paths).
It is the tenth Gyosho (training place for ascetics) of Omine Okugake-michi (paths).
It is the tenth Gyosho (training place for ascetics) of Omine Okugake-michi (paths).

sen.j: 国之常立神を祀っている数少ない神社の一つである。
sen.e: It is one of a few shrines that enshrine Kuninokototachi no mikoto.

sen.j: 「応保3年3月3日_(旧暦)甲午」（1163年4月15日）の紀年銘資料と梵字の銘がある。
sen.e: It has an inscription of the date April 15, 1163 and an inscription in Sanskrit characters.
sen.cmt: 紀年銘資料とその他梵字の銘があると解釈しました。
sen.e: It has an inscription of the date April 15, 1163 and an inscription in Sanskrit characters.

sen.j: 佐々木高綱の奉納ともいう。
sen.e: It is said to have been dedicated by Takatsuna SASAKI

sen.j: 十津川村歴史民俗資料館蔵。
sen.e: It is stored at Totsugawa Village history and race resource center.

sen.j: かつての別当寺である高牟婁院を改装したもの。
sen.e: It used to be a betto-ji temple called Takamuro-in, which was converted into the present office and kitchen.
It used to be a betto-ji temple called Takamuro-in, which was converted into the present office and kitchen.

sen.j: 書院造で、文化_(元号)元年（1804年）に建てられた。
sen.e: It was built in 1804 in a shoin style.

sen.e: Many of them are named: Jindai-sugi (3000 years old), Tokotachi-sugi, Yuware-sugi, etc.

sen.j: 室町時代風だが、後白河法皇の寄進と伝わる。
sen.e: It is a Muromachi Period style but said to have been donated by Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa

sen.j: 社伝では崇神天皇によって崇神天皇61年（紀元前37年）に創建されたという。
sen.e: The shrine tradition says that it was founded by Emperor Suijin in 37 B.C.
The shrine tradition says that it was founded by Emperor Suijin in 37 B.C.
The shrine tradition says that it was founded by Emperor Suijin in 37 B.C.

sen.j: 古来より十津川郷の鎮守神であった。
sen.e: It had been the village shrine god of the Totsugawa area since ancient times.
It had been the village shrine god of the Totsugawa area since ancient times.
It had been the village shrine god of the Totsugawa area since ancient times.

sen.j: 文献の記録は少ないが、寛政12年（1800年）の玉置山別当高牟婁院宛沙汰書には「玉置山は熊野三山の奥の院で格別の由緒があり」と書かれており、熊野本宮（現・和歌山県田辺市）に玉置神社の遥拝所があったという。
sen.e: There are not many written records about the shrine, but the imperial words documents of 1800 to Tamakiyama betto, Takamuro-in Shrine, says 'Tamaki-yama is the sacred place called Oku-no-in of Kumano Sanzan (Kumano three shrines) and has a special history' and it is said that there was a place to pray called Yohaisho in Kumano-hongu Shrine (Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture), where people can pray to Tamaki-jinja Shrine from the distance.

There are not many written records about the shrine, but the imperial words documents of 1800 to Tamakiyama betto, Takamuro-in Shrine, says 'Tamaki-yama is the sacred place called Oku-no-in of Kumano Sanzan (Kumano three shrines) and has a special history' and it is said that there was a place to pray called Yohaisho in Kumano-hongu Shrine (Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture), where people can pray to Tamaki-jinja Shrine from the distance.

There are not many written records about the shrine, but the imperial words documents of 1800 to Tamakiyama betto, Takamuro-in Shrine, says 'Tamaki-yama is the sacred place called Oku-no-in of Kumano Sanzan (Kumano three shrines) and has a special history' and it is said that there was a place to pray called Yohaisho in Kumano-hongu Shrine (Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture), where people can pray to Tamaki-jinja Shrine from the distance.

sen.j: 明治以前は京都の聖護院の配下にあって玉置三所権現とも呼ばれ、山中に7坊・15寺の神宮寺を備えた修験道場として栄えていた。
sen.e: Before the Meiji Period, it was under command of Shogo-in Shrine in Kyoto, also called Tamaki-Sansho-Gongen, and it prospered as a place for Shugendo doctrine with ７ monk's residences called bo and 15 temples in the mountain.

Before the Meiji Period, it was under command of Shogo-in Shrine in Kyoto, also called Tamaki-Sansho-Gongen, and it prospered as a place for Shugendo doctrine with ７ monk's residences called bo and 15 temples in the mountain.
